results.title: Citizen Kane (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Robert Wise, Orson Welles and Mercury Productions
results.brief_description: A faceless journalist sets out to investigate the life of media magnate and failed politician Charles Foster Kane. He seeks to uncover the meaning of “rosebud”, Kane’s last utterance. In turn satire, tragedy and gothic comedy, Citizen Kane is a triumph of disjointed, non-linear narrative in which the form becomes the theme, an ironic reflection upon the success ethic and the crushing weight of materialism. In drawing upon the tradition of classical narrative, while at the same time violating some of the expectations in the viewer’s reception of such narrative, Welles ultimately assured “Citizen Kane” of its place as a watershed in modern cinema. Credits: script-Herman J. Mankiewicz, Orson Welles; music-Bernard Hermann; photography-Gregg Toland; editors-Robert Wise, Mark Robson. Cast includes: Orson Welles, Joseph Cotten, Agnes Moorehead, Dorothy Comingore, Ray Collins, Everett Sloane.

results.title: The Good oil
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Law”.
A funny, true to life story about a group of residents and their conflict with a nearby factory management. The residents’ indignation over sleepless nights and spoiled washing has its funny moments but the way is opened for serious questions about our changing environment

results.title: Islands in the sky
results.creator_credit: Klaus Jaritz, Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the summer wildflowers in Kosciusko National Park. Discusses adaptation of the plants to the hostile environment and includes an alpine herb field, ferns and bogs.

results.title: Great coastal dune show
results.creator_credit: Andrew Prowse, Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the Department of Environment, Housing and Community Developments, this film adopts a satirical approach to the needs of a coastal dwelling nation like Australia actively trying to preserve coastline ecosystems. The film is short and its “message” is sharp: building on sand is insecure in more than one sense. Largely because of the humorous approach taken by the scriptwriter, the future impact of interference with dune communities should be felt by all audiences but, in particular, those who see the film in the classroom.

results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Tom Morrison, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission
results.brief_description: A film which shows how man is making heavy demands on the earth’s remaining forests. A detailed study is made of the ecology of a eucalypt forest and the many plants and animals which make up the forest environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Tom Morrison, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: David Hughes, Gerry Hudson, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film was made at the Melbourne Zoo and, without commentary, shows the activities - particularly eating - of birds in the air and animals on land and in water. There are some interesting close-ups of parts of animals, eg. the texture of the skin of a hippo and the back of an eagle.

results.title: You'd have to be mad to like opera
results.creator_credit: Ian Walker, Karl McPhee, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Explores the personality of opera singer Isobel Buchanan, and gives an insight into her life as an opera singer. She is seen in a number of situations which show the wide range of activities and disciplines which go towards the making of an opera. Particular emphasis is placed on rehearsal and actual performance of the opera ‘Don Pasquale’. Production manager, Roy Bissell; director, script, Karl McPhee; editor, Ian Walker; sound, Rodney Simmons; photographer, Andrew Fraser.

results.title: Woodcraftsman: Stephen Hogbin
results.creator_credit: Peter Drummond and Craft Association of Australia
results.brief_description: Canadian Stephen Hogbin, internationally acclaimed woodcraftsman, came to Australia for one year as craftsman in residence at the State College of Victoria, Melbourne. In Noojee State Forest, where the college camp is situated, Hogbin discovers the exciting possibilities of Australian timber. He communicates to students his enthusiasm for the use of wood in crafting.

results.title: Why wilderness?
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Shepparton South Technical School and Seymour High School
results.brief_description: Footage by students from Seymour High School and Shepparton South Technical School depicts the southwest of Tasmania. Commentary emphasises the importance for man to explore his surroundings and enjoy nature.

results.title: The Wetlands problem
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Australian Academy of Science, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: A case study of the Murray Darling River system which examines man’s relationship with his environment. Shows how the demands we have placed on this important river system for navigation, irrigation, water supply and recreation, have greatly altered it from its original condition. Poses the question, are we altering the ecology of the wetlands to a point where we may no longer derive the benefits we hope to enjoy from this river system?
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Australian Academy of Science, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
